description: From Middle English hunger, from Old English hungor (“hunger, desire; famine”), from Proto-Germanic *hungruz, *hunhruz (“hunger”), from Proto-Indo-European *kenk- (“to burn, smart, desire, hunger, thirst”). Cognate with West Frisian honger, hûnger (“hunger”), Dutch honger (“hunger”), German Low German Hunger (“hunger”), German Hunger (“hunger”), Swedish hunger (“hunger”), Icelandic hungur (“hunger”).

entries.meaning: A need or compelling desire for food.

examples: I have a hunger to win.

description: From Middle English hungren, from Old English hyngran, hyngrian, ġehyngrian (“to be hungry”), from Proto-Germanic *hungrijaną.

verbs.description: hunger (third-person singular simple present hungers, present participle hungering, simple past and past participle hungered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be in need of food.
(figuratively, intransitive, usually with 'for' or 'after') To have a desire (for); to long; to yearn.
(archaic, transitive) To make hungry; to famish.
